markdownRemark.html:
Describing Cardinality

  • Cardinality is the number of elements within a set
  • Cardinality is also referred to as the length of a set
  • We can represent a set of all ordered pairs of elements as the cartesian product of two sets
  • In other words, a cartesian product of two sets is the set of all ordered pairs of the elements within the two sets
  • For example, if A\text{A}A and B\text{B}B are sets, then A×B\text{A} \times \text{B}A×B is denoted as the cartesian product of A\text{A}A and B\text{B}B
  • Specifically, the cartesian product of A\text{A}A and B\text{B}B consists of the set of all ordered pairs of elements (a,b)(\text{a}, \text{b})(a,b) where a∈A\text{a} \in \text{A}a∈A and b∈B\text{b} \in \text{B}b∈B

Some Examples of Cardinality

  • Let's say we have the set {}\text{\textbraceleft}{}\text{\textbraceright}{}, then the cardinality of the set is the following:
∣{}∣=0|\text{\textbraceleft}{}\text{\textbraceright}| = 0∣{}∣=0
  • Let's say we have the set {{1},{1,2,3,4}}\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{\textbraceleft}{1}\text{\textbraceright}, \text{\textbraceleft}{1,2,3,4}\text{\textbraceright}}\text{\textbraceright}{{1},{1,2,3,4}}, then the cardinality of the set is the following:
∣{{1},{1,2,3,4}}∣=2|\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{\textbraceleft}{1}\text{\textbraceright}, \text{\textbraceleft}{1,2,3,4}\text{\textbraceright}}\text{\textbraceright}| = 2∣{{1},{1,2,3,4}}∣=2
  • Let's say we have the set {{},{2,{1,{}}}}\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{\textbraceleft}{}\text{\textbraceright}, \text{\textbraceleft}{2, \text{\textbraceleft}{1, \text{\textbraceleft}{}\text{\textbraceright}}\text{\textbraceright}}\text{\textbraceright}}\text{\textbraceright}{{},{2,{1,{}}}}, then the cardinality of the set is the following:
∣{{},{2,{1,{}}}}∣=2|\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{\textbraceleft}{}\text{\textbraceright}, \text{\textbraceleft}{2, \text{\textbraceleft}{1, \text{\textbraceleft}{}\text{\textbraceright}}\text{\textbraceright}}\text{\textbraceright}}\text{\textbraceright}| = 2∣{{},{2,{1,{}}}}∣=2

An Example of Cartesian Products

  • A very familiar example of a cartesian product is the xy-plane
  • In this case, we have ordered pairs of coordinates, where each coordinate is a real number
  • We can describe this as the cartesian product R×R\R \times \RR×R
  • Since we essentialy multiply R\RR by itself, we typically write this as R2\R^{2}R2 for short
  • Similarly, R3\R^{3}R3 or Rn\R^{n}Rn represent ordered triples or ordered n-tuples of real numbers, corresponding to a 3-dimensional and n-dimensional space, respectively
  • Specifically, R2\R^{2}R2 is the set {(1.222,4),(3,5),(7.9,910),...}\text{\textbraceleft}{(1.222,4), (3,5), (7.9,\frac{9}{10}), ...}\text{\textbraceright}{(1.222,4),(3,5),(7.9,109​),...}
  • More specifically, R2\R^{2}R2 doesn't contain elements (1)(1)(1) or (2,5,6)(2,5,6)(2,5,6) in its set

Another Example of Cartesian Products

  • Let's say we have the set {0,1}∞\text{\textbraceleft}{0,1}\text{\textbraceright}^{\infty}{0,1}∞ contains every unique element that is an infinitely long ordered pair of coordinates
  • Specifically, {0,1}∞\text{\textbraceleft}{0,1}\text{\textbraceright}^{\infty}{0,1}∞ is the set {(0,1,1,0,0,...),(1,1,1,1,...),...}\text{\textbraceleft}{(0,1,1,0,0,...),(1,1,1,1,...), ...}\text{\textbraceright}{(0,1,1,0,0,...),(1,1,1,1,...),...}
  • Therefore, this would be considered an infinite set

Describing Countable Sets

  • A set is countable if its cardinality is no greater than the cardinality of the natural numbers
  • Specifically, a set is countable if there is a bijection between the given set and the set of all natural numbers

Examples of Countable Sets

N\NN
  • This is the set of all natural numbers
  • Specifically, N\NN is the set {1,2,3,4,5,6,...}\text{\textbraceleft}{1,2,3,4,5,6,...}\text{\textbraceright}{1,2,3,4,5,6,...}
W\mathbb{W}W
  • This is the set of all whole numbers
  • Specifically, W\mathbb{W}W is the set {0,1,2,3,4,5,6,...}\text{\textbraceleft}{0,1,2,3,4,5,6,...}\text{\textbraceright}{0,1,2,3,4,5,6,...}
Z\mathbb{Z}Z
  • This is the set of all integers
  • Specifically, Z\mathbb{Z}Z is the set {...,−2,−1,0,1,2,...}\text{\textbraceleft}{...,-2,-1,0,1,2,...}\text{\textbraceright}{...,−2,−1,0,1,2,...}
Q\mathbb{Q}Q
  • This is the set of all rational numbers
  • Specifically, Q\mathbb{Q}Q is the set {...,−13,.12,78,216.836ˉ,...}\text{\textbraceleft}{...,-\frac{1}{3},.12,\frac{7}{8},216.83\bar{6},...}\text{\textbraceright}{...,−31​,.12,87​,216.836ˉ,...}

Examples of Uncountable Sets

C\mathbb{C}C
  • This is the set of all complex numbers
  • Specifically, C\mathbb{C}C is the set {...,3i+5,4i−8,...}\text{\textbraceleft}{...,3i+5,4i-8,...}\text{\textbraceright}{...,3i+5,4i−8,...}
R−Q\R - \mathbb{Q}R−Q
  • This is the set of all irrational numbers
  • Specifically, R−Q\R - \mathbb{Q}R−Q is any number that cannot be expressed using a fraction
R\RR
  • This is the set of all real numbers
  • Specifically, this is an uncountable set because it contains the set of all irrational numbers
{The set of all real numbers between 0 and 1}\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{The set of all real numbers between 0 and 1}}\text{\textbraceright}{The set of all real numbers between 0 and 1}

Finite Sets

  • Roughly speaking, a finite set is a set in which one could in principle count and finish counting
  • The following are some examples of finite sets:
{1,2,3,4,...,1000}\text{\textbraceleft}{1,2,3,4,...,1000}\text{\textbraceright}{1,2,3,4,...,1000} {−100,−99,−98,...,1000000000000}\text{\textbraceleft}{-100,-99,-98,...,1000000000000}\text{\textbraceright}{−100,−99,−98,...,1000000000000} {A set with a cardinality of 2478}\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{A set with a cardinality of 2478}}\text{\textbraceright}{A set with a cardinality of 2478} {A set with a cardinality of 1000000000000000000000000000}\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{A set with a cardinality of 1000000000000000000000000000}}\text{\textbraceright}{A set with a cardinality of 1000000000000000000000000000}
  • The following are some examples of infinite sets:
{The set of all even numbers}\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{The set of all even numbers}}\text{\textbraceright}{The set of all even numbers} {The set of all odd numbers}\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{The set of all odd numbers}}\text{\textbraceright}{The set of all odd numbers}

More on Countability

  • A finite set is a subset of a countable set
  • In other words, all finite sets are countable, but not all countable sets are finite
  • There are countably finite and countable infinite sets, but there are no such thing as uncountable finite sets
  • A countable infinite set is the smallest infinite set

Power Sets

  • The Cartesian product consists of ordered pairs of elements where the length of each pair is determined by the power raised (or the dimension)
  • The ordered pairs in this case are technically considered sets
  • The power set consists of subsets of some set SSS
  • Again, we can denote cartesian products as S×SS \times SS×S or S2S^{2}S2 if SSS is some set
  • Let's say we have the following set:
S={1,2,3}S = \text{\textbraceleft}{1,2,3}\text{\textbraceright}S={1,2,3}
  • Then, we can define a catesian product and powerset of this set as the following:
S×S={(1,1),(1,2),(1,3),(2,1),(2,2),(2,3),(3,1),(3,2),(3,3)}S \times S = \text{\textbraceleft}{(1,1),(1,2),(1,3),(2,1),(2,2),(2,3),(3,1),(3,2),(3,3)}\text{\textbraceright}S×S={(1,1),(1,2),(1,3),(2,1),(2,2),(2,3),(3,1),(3,2),(3,3)} PowerSet(S)={{∅},{1},{2},{3},{1,2},{1,3},{2,3},{1,2,3}}PowerSet(S) = \text{\textbraceleft}{\text{\textbraceleft}{∅}\text{\textbraceright},\text{\textbraceleft}{1}\text{\textbraceright},\text{\textbraceleft}{2}\text{\textbraceright},\text{\textbraceleft}{3}\text{\textbraceright},\text{\textbraceleft}{1,2}\text{\textbraceright},\text{\textbraceleft}{1,3}\text{\textbraceright},\text{\textbraceleft}{2,3}\text{\textbraceright},\text{\textbraceleft}{1,2,3}\text{\textbraceright}}\text{\textbraceright}PowerSet(S)={{∅},{1},{2},{3},{1,2},{1,3},{2,3},{1,2,3}}
